description:
Christensenella massiliensis is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from a human stool sample collected in Marseille, France. It is a Gram-negative, anaerobic, non-spore-forming, rod-shaped bacterium that belongs to the phylum Firmicutes and the family Christensenellaceae.

The cells of C. massiliensis are approximately 0.5-0.8 μm wide and 1.2-2.5 μm long. They are motile, with the presence of peritrichous flagella. The bacterium is chemoorganotrophic, meaning it obtains its energy through the oxidation of organic compounds.

Phylogenetic analysis based on the 16S rRNA gene sequence has shown that C. massiliensis is closely related to other members of the genus Christensenella, which are known to be part of the human gut microbiome and have been associated with various health benefits.

Further studies on the physiological and genomic characteristics of C. massiliensis, as well as its potential role in human health and disease, are ongoing to better understand its ecological and functional significance within the human gut ecosystem.
